Blood flows away from the heart to arteries, which follow into arterioles, and
then narrow further into capillaries. After the tissue has been perfused,
capillaries branch and widen to become venules and then widen more and connect
to become veins, which return blood to the heart. | Precursor = | System = |

'Capillaries' () are the smallest of a body's blood vessels and are parts of
the microcirculation. Their endothelial linings are only one cell layer thick.
These microvessels, measuring 5-10 Î¼m in diameter, connect arterioles and
venules, and enable the exchange of water, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and many
other nutrients and waste chemical substances between blood and surrounding
tissues. {{cite book

  | 0-13-981176-1}} During embryological development, new capillaries are
